to_embed: Case-based reasoning adapts past solutions for new problems, fueled by application growth and memory-intensive techniques.

metadata.title: Case-Based Reasoning for Problem Solving
metadata.description: Case-based reasoning (CBR) is used to solve new problems by adapting solutions from similar past problems. This approach is gaining momentum due to increasing applications and interest in memory-intensive techniques.
metadata.source: Special Issue on Case Based Reasoning, 2017.0

metadata.title: Efficient Problem Solving
metadata.description: CBR enables efficient problem-solving by leveraging past experiences, reducing the need for novel solutions in every instance. It enhances adaptability and speeds up decision-making processes.
metadata.source: Special Issue on Case Based Reasoning, 2017.0

metadata.title: Over-Reliance on Past Cases
metadata.description: Over-reliance on past cases might lead to suboptimal solutions if the new problem has unique aspects not adequately represented in the existing case base. This can result in ineffective or even harmful outcomes.
metadata.source: Special Issue on Case Based Reasoning, 2017.0

metadata.title: Regular Case Base Updates
metadata.description: Regularly update and expand the case base to include diverse and representative cases. Implement methods for identifying and adapting to novel situations not covered by existing cases to reduce risks.
metadata.source: Special Issue on Case Based Reasoning, 2017.0

to_embed: AI-enhanced military simulations improve war outcome predictions and strategic decision-making for the international community.

metadata.title: AI-Enhanced War Simulations
metadata.description: AI models can enhance military simulations and wargames, improving the accuracy of outcome predictions and strategic decision-making by incorporating factors beyond attrition.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Improved Strategic Decisions
metadata.description: AI-enhanced simulations lead to better-informed strategic decisions, potentially reducing conflict escalation and improving resource allocation in military operations.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Bias in Simulation Outcomes
metadata.description: AI models trained on incomplete or biased data may produce skewed simulation outcomes, leading to flawed strategic decisions and potentially escalating conflicts.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Data Diversification
metadata.description: Employ diverse and representative datasets for training AI models to minimize bias and ensure simulation outcomes reflect a broader range of potential scenarios.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

to_embed: AI-driven C4ISR optimization for enhanced battlefield situation awareness and improved military effectiveness.

metadata.title: AI-Optimized C4ISR
metadata.description: AI algorithms can optimize Command, Control, Communications, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) systems, enhancing battlefield situation awareness and improving military effectiveness.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Enhanced Situation Awareness
metadata.description: Improved situation awareness through AI-optimized C4ISR leads to more effective resource allocation, faster response times, and reduced casualties in military operations.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Over-Reliance on AI
metadata.description: Excessive reliance on AI-optimized C4ISR systems can lead to vulnerabilities if the AI is compromised or fails, potentially resulting in strategic disadvantages.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

metadata.title: Redundancy and Oversight
metadata.description: Implement redundant systems and human oversight to mitigate the risks of AI failure or compromise in C4ISR systems, ensuring continued operational effectiveness.
metadata.source: Entropy-Based Warfare: Modeling the Revolution in Military Affairs (Joint Force Quarterly, Autumn/Winter, 1998-1999), 1999.0

to_embed: AI modeling and systems for military-industrial problem-solving, benefiting defense and related sectors.

metadata.title: AI for Military-Industrial Problem Solving
metadata.description: AI applications in modeling and building systems to solve problems primarily within the military-industrial sector, enhancing defense capabilities and strategic decision-making.
metadata.source: OR Forum - The Keynote Speech, 1989.0

metadata.title: Enhanced Defense Capabilities
metadata.description: AI-driven solutions can lead to more effective defense strategies, improved resource allocation, and faster response times in critical situations.
metadata.source: OR Forum - The Keynote Speech, 1989.0

metadata.title: Potential for Misuse
metadata.description: The use of AI in the military-industrial sector carries the risk of misuse, leading to unintended harm, escalation of conflicts, or violations of human rights.
metadata.source: OR Forum - The Keynote Speech, 1989.0

metadata.title: Ethical Oversight
metadata.description: Establishing strict ethical guidelines, transparency, and human oversight in the development and deployment of AI systems can help prevent misuse and ensure accountability.
metadata.source: OR Forum - The Keynote Speech, 1989.0

to_embed: Computerized systems enhance military information gathering, processing, and dissemination for efficient enemy engagement.

metadata.title: AI-Enhanced Military Intelligence
metadata.description: AI-driven systems improve information gathering, processing, and dissemination within the military, enabling fewer personnel to effectively engage larger enemy forces through superior intelligence.
metadata.source: Inside risks: Computers as substitute soldiers?, 1995.0

metadata.title: Reduced Casualties
metadata.description: Improved intelligence and precision targeting through AI can lead to reduced friendly losses in military engagements, as suggested by the Gulf War example.
metadata.source: Inside risks: Computers as substitute soldiers?, 1995.0

metadata.title: Over-Reliance on Tech
metadata.description: Over-dependence on computerized systems could lead to vulnerabilities if these systems are compromised or fail, potentially negating the advantage gained.
metadata.source: Inside risks: Computers as substitute soldiers?, 1995.0

metadata.title: Redundancy and Resilience
metadata.description: Implement redundant systems and contingency plans to ensure operational capability even if primary computerized systems are compromised or unavailable.
metadata.source: Inside risks: Computers as substitute soldiers?, 1995.0

to_embed: PACEXTRA: Microcomputer-based crisis action executive training system for individual exercises and interactive task coordination.

metadata.title: Crisis Action Executive Training System
metadata.description: PACEXTRA provides individual crisis action executive trainees exercises, intellectual and coordinative tasks, conducted interactively on a microcomputer. Includes authoring system for exercise creation.
metadata.source: PACEXTRA: Pacific Air Forces Crisis Action System Executive Training System, 1992.0

metadata.title: Improved Decision-Making Skills
metadata.description: PACEXTRA provides a simulated environment for trainees to develop and refine decision-making skills through practical experience, which may lead to better crisis management.
metadata.source: PACEXTRA: Pacific Air Forces Crisis Action System Executive Training System, 1992.0

metadata.title: Over-Reliance on Simulations
metadata.description: Trainees might become overly reliant on the simulated environment and struggle to adapt to unexpected situations in real-world crisis scenarios.
metadata.source: PACEXTRA: Pacific Air Forces Crisis Action System Executive Training System, 1992.0

metadata.title: Real-World Exercises
metadata.description: Supplement simulation training with real-world exercises and field training to expose trainees to unpredictable factors and foster adaptability.
metadata.source: PACEXTRA: Pacific Air Forces Crisis Action System Executive Training System, 1992.0

to_embed: Information systems design using problem type analysis by Cyert and March for organizations.

metadata.title: Problem-Type Driven IS Design
metadata.description: Using the problem classifications of Cyert and March to inform the design and development of information systems in organizations to improve problem-solving.
metadata.source: Why we Need to Distinguish between Problem Solving Types in Information Systems Design, 1999.0

metadata.title: Improved System Alignment
metadata.description: Ensures information systems are tailored to the specific problem types, leading to more effective solutions and improved organizational performance.
metadata.source: Why we Need to Distinguish between Problem Solving Types in Information Systems Design, 1999.0

metadata.title: Potential Oversimplification
metadata.description: Over-reliance on the framework could lead to oversimplification of complex problems, neglecting nuances and potentially causing inadequate solutions.
metadata.source: Why we Need to Distinguish between Problem Solving Types in Information Systems Design, 1999.0

metadata.title: Multi-faceted Analysis
metadata.description: Combine the Cyert and March framework with other problem-solving methodologies and expert consultations to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the issue.
metadata.source: Why we Need to Distinguish between Problem Solving Types in Information Systems Design, 1999.0

to_embed: AI-powered Intelligence Analysis for improved decision-making in national security and policy development benefiting policymakers.

metadata.title: AI for Intelligence Analysis
metadata.description: AI algorithms are used to analyze intelligence data, assisting policymakers in national security by providing insights derived from data, as informed by Dr. Lowenthal's experience.
metadata.source: About the Contributors, 2008.0

metadata.title: Enhanced Policy Making
metadata.description: AI-driven analysis improves the quality and timeliness of intelligence, which enables more informed and effective decision-making in national security and foreign policy.
metadata.source: About the Contributors, 2008.0

metadata.title: Bias in Analysis
metadata.description: AI algorithms may perpetuate biases present in the training data, leading to skewed intelligence assessments and potentially flawed policy recommendations. It might cause unintended consequences.
metadata.source: About the Contributors, 2008.0

metadata.title: Data Diversity
metadata.description: Ensure training data is diverse and representative to minimize bias. Implement auditing processes to detect and correct biases in AI outputs and integrate human oversight in the analysis process.
metadata.source: About the Contributors, 2008.0

to_embed: AI-driven reflective equilibrium model enhancing moral reasoning by integrating parallel constraint satisfaction, benefiting individuals and society.

metadata.title: AI for Reflective Equilibrium in Moral Reasoning
metadata.description: Using AI and parallel constraint satisfaction models to enhance moral reasoning towards a reflective equilibrium. Aiding in complex moral decisions by considering multiple factors.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

to_embed: AI for Reflective Equilibrium in Moral Reasoning

metadata.title: Improved Moral Decisions
metadata.description: Enhances moral decision-making by providing a more comprehensive and balanced approach through the integration of multiple constraints and perspectives.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

to_embed: AI for Reflective Equilibrium in Moral Reasoning

metadata.title: Bias Amplification
metadata.description: AI models might amplify existing biases in training data, leading to skewed or unfair moral judgments, especially if data reflects societal prejudices.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

metadata.title: Data Auditing & Fairness Metrics
metadata.description: Implement thorough data auditing procedures to identify and correct biases, and utilize fairness metrics to evaluate and improve the AI model's impartiality.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

to_embed: AI assisting in understanding unconscious reasoning processes by analyzing patterns and predicting outcomes.

metadata.title: AI for Unconscious Reasoning Analysis
metadata.description: Using AI to analyze patterns in decision-making to understand unconscious reasoning processes. Application in behavioral science and psychology.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

metadata.title: Deeper Self-Understanding
metadata.description: Provides insights into hidden biases and influences affecting decision-making, leading to greater self-awareness and improved personal choices.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

metadata.title: Over-Interpretation of Data
metadata.description: AI may incorrectly interpret data patterns, leading to flawed understanding of unconscious reasoning and potentially harmful interventions.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

metadata.title: Human Oversight
metadata.description: Maintain human oversight in interpreting AI-generated insights, ensuring conclusions are critically evaluated and validated against other evidence.
metadata.source: Notes on practical reasoning, 2011.0

to_embed: VirtualECare GDSS uses Multi-valued Extended Logic Programming for knowledge evaluation in online healthcare services.

metadata.title: Knowledge Evaluation in VirtualECare Group Decision Support System
metadata.description: The application addresses knowledge evaluation in a VirtualECare Group Decision Supporting System, utilizing Multi-valued Extended Logic Programming to handle incomplete and uncertain healthcare knowledge, aiming to sustain online healthcare services.
metadata.source: Quality of Knowledge in Group Decision Support Systems, 2009.0

to_embed: Knowledge Evaluation in VirtualECare Group Decision Support System

metadata.title: Responsible Healthcare Decisions
metadata.description: It benefits society by enabling more responsible and timely decisions in online healthcare services, even when dealing with incomplete or uncertain knowledge, thereby reducing the risk of negative health outcomes.
metadata.source: Quality of Knowledge in Group Decision Support Systems, 2009.0

to_embed: Knowledge Evaluation in VirtualECare Group Decision Support System

metadata.title: Inaccurate Knowledge Evaluation
metadata.description: The risk involves potential inaccuracies in knowledge evaluation due to the complexity of Multi-valued Extended Logic Programming, potentially leading to incorrect decisions and adverse patient outcomes, affecting human rights to proper care.
metadata.source: Quality of Knowledge in Group Decision Support Systems, 2009.0

metadata.title: Rigorous Validation
metadata.description: Rigorous validation and testing of the Multi-valued Extended Logic Programming implementation can mitigate the risk by identifying and correcting potential errors, thereby improving the accuracy of knowledge evaluation.
metadata.source: Quality of Knowledge in Group Decision Support Systems, 2009.0
